#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Scottish Justice Secretary ' acutely aware of unusual publicity ' in Kular case
#Text=Thursday , February 13 , 2014

#Text=Wikinews has obtained a letter by Scottish Justice Secretary Kenny MacAskill to former Conservative justice spokesman John Lamont in response to questions raised by our correspondent about the Mikaeel Kular murder case .

#Text=Wikinews has investigated possible contempt by media publishing potentially prejudicial material , and MacAskill wrote he has " been following the case of Mikaeel Kular and [ is ] acutely aware of the unusual publicity this case has attracted . "
#Text=Kenny MacAskill in his official Parliamentary portrait .
#Text=Image : Scottish Government .
#Text=When Mikaeel Kular , three , vanished from his Edinburgh home last month
#Text=police and volunteers scoured the capital for him .
#Text=His body was found in Fife just before midnight on January 17 , and his mother was arrested on January 18 .
#Text=That 's when Wikinews first reported on possible widespread contempt by UK and Scottish media .
#Text=Our correspondent is based in Scotland and has been advised by a lawyer not to identify anybody detained until they have appeared in court , even if they have been arrested and charged .
#Text=Professor James Chalmers of the University of Glasgow has since reviewed our coverage and confirmed this position .
#Text=Despite that a large number of major media outlets identified Rosdeep Adekoya , nee Kular , 33 , as the arrested individual .
#Text=Adekoya has since been in Edinburgh Sheriff Court charged with murdering her son .
#Text=She is in custody pending indictment and trial , but any eyewitness evidence may be tainted because her image has been widely published .
#Text=This is common practice elsewhere in the UK but Scottish justice works differently and courts have viewed publication of photos as potentially prejudicial .
#Text=Professor Pamela Ferguson of the University of Dundee notes " journalists do seem to be walking a dangerous line if publishing photos etc of suspects . "
#Text=Crown Office , which is in overall charge of prosecutions , has indicated to journalists that no further comment will be made at least until indictment .
#Text=File photo of Edinburgh Sheriff Court , where Adekoya has appeared accused of murdering her son .
#Text=Image : Tharnton345 .
#Text=MacAskill however expressed confidence in the Scottish court system to deal with the situation .
#Text=" I am confident ...

#Text=The courts have said that the only safe route to avoid committing a contempt is to avoid publishing a photograph , but that does not mean that publishing a photograph is automatically a contempt .

_	_	_	_

#Text=MacAskill noted  the kind of issue that publicity might raise may become apparent only during the trial itself . "

column1: #Text=Contempt has been a considerable issue in the UK in recent years after high-profile cases .

#Text=In one instance a charge against serial killer Levi Bellfield was dropped owing to publicity while the jury were deliberating ; in another , newspapers were fined and sued for libel over reporting on the arrest of a suspect who turned out to be innocent in a prominent investigation .
#Text=A proposal was mooted to ban identification of suspects arrested anywhere in the UK , but this was subsequently shelved .
#Text=MacAskill confirmed " the Scottish Government is content with the way the courts are operating the rules on contempt of court in Scotland at the moment and has no plans to make changes . "

#Text=He also wrote of the difficulties with trying to individually cover all eventualities with prescriptive legislation , saying " A trial for a sexual offence will raise very different issues — particularly of protecting victims — from those that are raised by a tax fraud trial . "

#Text=MacAskill says it is the Scottish Government 's position that the task of " counterbalancing the public interest in reporting with upholding the criminal law should be left to those whose job it is to do so — the courts and the judiciary , acting in the individual circumstances of the case " .
